fields.Title: Flow – PLAZA / SUGGESTION JACKET EPIC / Flow – EPIC SUGGESTION
fields.Condition: IsKimHere() == true  and  CheckEquipped("jacket_fucktheworld")  and  FlagSet("plaza.jacket_suggestion_need_triggered")  and  FlagSet("plaza.jacket_suggestion_convo_played") == false--[[ Variable[ ]]

fields.Dialogue Text: There's another way we can go with this: *Frame-control*. Flip the situation on its head. Make them play by *your rules*.
"Damnit, detective. Give me the piss-jacket."
fields.Sequence:
PostFX(blackout-world, true)@0.5; LuaRun(SetAreaState("KIM_PF_JACKET", "on"))@2.4; PostFX(blackout-world, false)@2.5; 
PlayAnimation(Kim Kitsuragi, Jacket)@3;

fields.annotation_text:
* Triggers when:
   * IsKimHere == true
   * The player has equipped the FTW-jacket

fields.Dialogue Text: Feels like you've failed the biggest shit-test of them all...
"The 'cool-factor' might hit me later." The lieutenant fingers the brown studded lapels. "Right now it feels like a joke gone too far."
Now he is become the *Pissf****t*. There's no stopping you now.
But the lieutenant isn't going to shit-test you. You've got multiple valid options here.
"You said you'd wear 'Pissf****t', but you realised you're more 'Fuck-the-World'. And that's totally fine..."
Hold on... 'Frame-control'? 'I-wanna-have-fuck-with-you' kind of frame-control?
"Weird, it looked *so* much cooler in my head."
With a look of utter disbelief the lieutenant slips into the jacket...
fields.Sequence:
PostFX(blackout-world, true)@0.5; LuaRun(SetAreaState("KIM_PF_JACKET", "on"))@2.4; PostFX(blackout-world, false)@2.5; 
PlayAnimation(Kim Kitsuragi, Jacket)@3;

fields.Dialogue Text: A shit-test is something wömen give men to see how strong their frame is, how confident they are. Fail it and they'll bail for another, more dominant alpha-male. It's in their nature.
Good. Step one complete. Now, let the lieutenant feast his eyes on the fruit of the tree of cool.
"No-no, Kim. We *just* committed to the bit. We gotta stick with it for a while."
'What was that, that's not how woooooords are used, say it again', giggles-giggles. Classic shit-test. That was your chance to just *own* it.
"Mhm. This is one of those times where you're just going to keep talking no matter what I say, isn't it?"
"You mean any more than I already am?" He looks around. "We better solve this case *fast* officer. I'm not 100% comfortable with this."
Doesn't need to, your shit is compact as a diamond.
A long moment passes as the lieutenant considers his words.
"Yes, you're really showing off that... aggressive slogan there."
If you can't even wear it outside for everyone to see then yes, time to abandon rock and roll.
Yawn and stretch like a leather-clad panther.
"That's not what I was saying, detective."
"The odds are *very high*, officer. It's situations like this that make me afraid I'll end up being the cretin-cop with 'Pissf****t' on his back..."
"The odds are *quite* high," the lieutenant replies, rubbing his forehead. "It doesn't care if we're in leather jackets that say 'Fuck the World' and 'Pissf****t' on their backs..."
"Oh, *I* see... Look, I can wear the 'Pissfa***t' jacket if that's the problem."
"Let's be clear about one thing. The first chance I get, this thing's coming off. And that will be it -- no take-backs, no 'follow-up conversations', that's it. Do you understand?"
"The RCM isn't gonna solve this, Kim. You and I are. Together." (Hold out the jacket.)

fields.annotation_text: "Rock and roll," marks the lieutenant with a sardonic smile. "But is now really the best time to fight the system?"

fields.Dialogue Text: "Wish you could see yourself right now, Kim." (Wipe your eye.)
"Alright, Fuck," the lieutenant turns to you. "Time to solve a murder, as counter-intuitive as it might seem in these jackets. Let's go."
I can't believe I've climbed aboard the piss-train.
"Kim, you and I -- this dynamo duo -- me in the 'Fuck the World' jacket and you in that old bomber jacket... Visually it just doesn't make sense any more."
"Lieutenant, I'm gonna be honest for a moment: You look like shit."
"I know exactly what you're trying to do, detective, and it's *not* going to work."
He sighs. "I'm afraid the RCM is going to have our asses for this."

fields.annotation_text:
* When Harry removes the jacket, so does kim. It must give out a boolean, et sa ei saaks post-trib küsida, et miks sa enam kusetagi ei kanna?

* Kim putting on the jacket gives out a boolean that's set to false when he takes it off or after tribunal.
* Using that boolean ctrl+f articy for post 3 day content that shouldhave reactivity for the jakcet. And add reactivity to parenthethics.
  * tribunal
  * fishing village
  * date stuff
  * church stuff
  * coast stuff
* ... he says, while wearing a jacket saying pissfa***t on it's back
* ... he adjusts the corner of his crude jacket.

fields.Dialogue Text: Of course, if being outside, looking like a rock-lion is making you 'feel silly', then just drop the whole thing.

'Subtle' like the aesthetic cacophony the two of you are making right now? Look at this shit. The visual fields make no sense. You're like a pair of white socks in brown sandals right now. It's disgusting.
"Piss and Fuck on the case, all-in, busting the bank!"
"It's..." the lieutenant slowly shakes his head, "not a good look. Doesn't exactly signal shit-together-ness."
It was sub-par delivery, not a lack of technique that failed you there. You could've still saved it, had you not failed her shit-test.
"The problem is..." the lieutenant says, glancing at the lapels, sleeves, and studs, "it really *does* look cool to have both of these jackets on right now."
Wait, what 'shit-test'?
"Detective... what are you talking about?"
"I agree. Fortunately we have plenty of work to occupy us. Let's get back to it."
I feel silly. People are looking. I'm gonna take it off. (Discard thought.)
"It's okay, Kim. Here, you take this one. *I'm* the Pissf****t now."
"That's what I'm afraid of," he mumbles. More to himself than anyone else. "We better solve this thing fast."
Plough ahead! Don't let him slow you down.
He means it. The moment your jacket comes off, so does his. That means you're probably going to have to keep fucking the world till the end of days.
He's looking around nervously, regrets putting the jacket on, wants to take it off.
"Never has anyone asked me to place more trust in them than you're asking of me, right now. If you saw this branch out from under me while I've got 'Pissf****t' written on my back..."
"Alright, that was fun. But not really," he adds, slipping back into his familiar bomber. "Enough time wasted. Let's get back to work."
fields.Sequence: PlayAnimation(Kim Kitsuragi, Dislikes); PostFX(blackout-world, true)@3; LuaRun(SetAreaState("KIM_PF_JACKET", "off"))@4.7; PostFX(blackout-world, false)@5;

fields.Dialogue Text: This is not how one gives speeches, milord -- why antagonise the lieutenant? Try again.
"Look at us, Kim! This is how we were meant to be."
Do a little twirl.
"It's not a problem. Here, *I'll* put on the Pissf****t jacket right now..."
"Tell me, Kim: What are the odds that after *all that* they fail to solve the case while wearing these two jackets?"
"I can't believe you talked me into this," he mumbles. "We better solve this thing fast."
"I disagree," he says with a small nod. "In fact if we were to do a poll right now, a little 'who looks like shit'-poll, I'm fairly confident you'd come out on top."
It was a rough morning, let's not revisit it.
"Forget it, this was a stupid idea." (Abandon the effort.)
You've got to work your way into this thing. The subtle way. Wind him up a little, don't immediately go for the kill.
"Imagine two cops, who've only known each other for a few days, yet such is their devotion, their bond, that they don *these* two jackets -- 'Fuck the World' and 'Pissf****t'..."
"Very rock and roll, but is now really the time?"
Fine, go with whatever you want. You have multiple solid options.
"You will *not* regret this, lieutenant!"
Officer in the bag! Officer in the bag!
"Fortunately for you, I'm *still* holding on to this sweet-as-fuck 'Pissf****t" jacket... Funny how life is sometimes..."
Shake the lapels of your jacket and look at the lieutenant defiantly.
